title: Cyprus objects to ancient vase being sold at auction after being given to Margaret Thatcher as an official gift
text:
Cyprus is to seek an explanation from the UK as to how an ancient vase that was given as a gift to Margaret Thatcher when she was prime minister came to be sold at auction.

Cypriots say the vase was given to the British state, rather than to Mrs Thatcher as an individual, and should have remained in government ownership.

The foreign minister of Cyprus is to raise the issue with the British High Commissioner in Nicosia.

The vase, which dates back to the 7th century BC, was presented to Mrs Thatcher in 1988 by George Vassiliou, the then president of Cyprus.

He had received special permission from the country’s antiquities department for the artefact to leave the country.

In Britain, the ministerial code stipulates that ministers, including the Prime Minister, may keep gifts only if they are worth less than £140, unless they dig into their own pockets and buy the objects themselves.

Mr Vassiliou's wife said she was dismayed that the vase was sold at a Christie’s auction in May.

“I am sure my husband will be very disappointed. After Mrs Thatcher ceased to be PM, this ancient pottery, which was a gift, should have found its place at 10 Downing Street. It should certainly not be sold by her heirs. It was not a personal gift,” Androulla Vassiliou, a former EU commissioner for education and culture, wrote on Twitter.
description: Cyprus is to seek an explanation from the UK as to how an ancient vase that was given as a gift to Margaret Thatcher when she was prime minister came to be sold at auction.
